content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple (approximately 6) pieces of tissue, consistent with lymph nodes resected from a colorectal cancer case. The tissues are embedded in pale, web-like adipose tissue. Several of the tissue fragments contain prominent dark purple (basophilic) areas, which represent dense lymphoid cell populations. Some of these nodes appear enlarged and almost entirely replaced by this cellular component, raising suspicion for metastatic disease or a lymphoproliferative disorder.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my primary task is to systematically examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The selected area (the first lymph node from the top-left) is a prime candidate for initial examination because it is a well-defined, discrete node that appears almost entirely composed of a dark, cellular infiltrate. This complete effacement of normal architecture is highly abnormal and requires high-magnification assessment to determine if it's due to metastatic carcinoma or another pathological process. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is the largest lymph node on the slide (the first one from the top left) and it appears almost completely effaced by tumor. My primary goal is to confirm the presence of metastasis. Specifically, I am focusing on the edge of the tumor deposit where it meets the surrounding fat. This interface is the most critical area to evaluate for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the spread of cancer cells beyond the lymph node capsule into the perinodal adipose tissue. ENE is a significant adverse prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it corresponds to the first lymph node from the top left. At low magnification, this node appears almost entirely replaced by a dense, dark blue (basophilic) cellular infiltrate, which is a classic appearance for a positive lymph node containing metastatic tumor. I need to examine this at higher magnification to confirm the presence of malignant cells and to characterize their morphology. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my goal is to examine every piece of tissue to identify all positive lymph nodes for accurate staging. While several nodes appear obviously positive, this large fragment on the bottom-left is more ambiguous from a distance. The green box highlights a focal area that is more basophilic and cellular than the surrounding fibroadipose tissue. This focus is suspicious for a small metastatic deposit within a mostly fatty-replaced lymph node or a discrete tumor deposit (satellite nodule). High-magnification is required to characterize these cells and determine if this represents a positive node, which is critical for the final pN stage. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to examine every single lymph node to determine if cancer has spread. I am systematically reviewing each node on the slide. The green box is placed over the third lymph node from the top on the right side. While other nodes appear more overtly positive, it is crucial to examine all of them, as even small or seemingly normal nodes can contain micrometastases. I am zooming in to assess the architecture and cellular details of this specific node to look for any evidence of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. This is the lymph node located at the top right of the slide. It clearly contains a large, basophilic focus suspicious for metastasis. I am zooming into this area to confirm the malignant nature of the cellular infiltrate and, importantly, to examine the interface between the tumor, the lymph node capsule, and the surrounding perinodal fat. This assessment is critical to determine if there is extranodal extension (tumor breaching the capsule), which is a significant prognostic factor in staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is a distinct lymph node that, even at low magnification, appears highly suspicious for metastasis. It is the first lymph node from the top right. The node shows a large, densely cellular, basophilic deposit occupying a significant portion of its architecture. The purpose of zooming in is to confirm at higher magnification that these cells are malignant (i.e., metastatic carcinoma) and to assess their morphology and the extent of their spread within the node, including looking for potential extension beyond the lymph node capsule (extranodal extension). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it corresponds to the first lymph node from the top on the right side. This node shows a large, dark purple area that is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma replacing the normal lymphoid tissue. Examination at higher power is necessary to confirm the presence of malignant cells, assess their morphology (e.g., gland formation, nuclear atypia), and evaluate the interface with the lymph node capsule and surrounding fat to check for extranodal extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is clearly a lymph node that contains a prominent, discrete, dark purple (basophilic) focus. In the context of colorectal cancer staging, the primary goal when examining lymph nodes is to identify metastasis. This suspicious area requires high-magnification examination to confirm whether it is metastatic adenocarcinoma or a benign reactive process. This specific node is the first one from the top on the right side of the image. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense, monotonous infiltrate of small, round lymphocytes with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. These cells completely replace the normal lymph node architecture, effacing the sinuses and germinal centers. There are no definitive features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as atypical glands, large pleomorphic cells, or significant necrosis. My impression is that this lymph node is involved by a low-grade B-cell lymphoma, most likely Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma/Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (SLL/CLL), given the uniform cytology. This would represent a second, co-incidental malignancy. Immunohistochemical stains would be necessary to confirm this diagnosis and definitively rule out a metastasis from a poorly differentiated carcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see two distinct regions. The bottom part of the image is composed of a dense sheet of malignant cells with large, dark, irregular nuclei, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. The top part of the image consists of mature adipose tissue (fat cells). The key finding is at the junction between these two areas. The tumor cells are clearly infiltrating past the fibrous lymph node capsule and are present within the surrounding adipose tissue, often in direct contact with adipocytes. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node with definite extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the lymph node architecture is largely effaced and replaced by sheets of malignant cells. These cells are arranged in poorly-formed, back-to-back glands and solid nests. The tumor cells show significant atypia with large, irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei and prominent nucleoli. There is also evidence of extensive apoptosis and necrosis (the scattered dark debris). On the right, I can see the fibrous capsule of the lymph node adjacent to mature adipose tissue. My impression is that this is unequivocally metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming this is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a lymph node partially replaced by tumor. On the right side of the image, there is a rim of residual lymphoid tissue, identifiable by the dense population of small, dark lymphocytes. The majority of the nodule is composed of infiltrative, irregularly shaped, and fused malignant glands characteristic of adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells show significant nuclear atypia, including hyperchromasia and pleomorphism. The tumor is surrounded by a fibrous capsule and is embedded in mature adipose tissue. My impression is definitive: this is a lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the preserved architecture of a lymph node. There is a prominent lymphoid follicle with a reactive germinal center, which is the slightly paler, circular area at the center of the field. The surrounding cells are predominantly small, mature lymphocytes. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular formations, or other features of metastatic carcinoma in this specific field of view. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, showing benign follicular hyperplasia. This part of the lymph node appears negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The magnified view shows a lymph node partially replaced by metastatic adenocarcinoma. The tumor consists of crowded, irregularly shaped glands and solid nests of malignant cells with large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. This infiltrate is adjacent to a band of residual lymphoid tissue. A fibrous capsule separates the nodal tissue from the surrounding perinodal fat. In this specific field, the tumor appears to be contained within the capsule. The definitive diagnosis for this node is metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense sheet of malignant cells with large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei, replacing the normal lymphoid tissue. The cells are cohesive and show some glandular or nested arrangement, characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The surrounding pink fibrous tissue represents the lymph node capsule. My impression is that this is unequivocally a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a clear demarcation between two tissue types. On the right, there is a dense, sheet-like infiltration of malignant cells with large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. The normal lymphoid architecture is effaced. On the left, there is perinodal adipose tissue and some fibrous connective tissue. The line between them appears to be the lymph node capsule. My impression is that this is a lymph node positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense, back-to-back proliferation of atypical epithelial cells. These cells are arranged in poorly formed, cribriform, and solid glandular structures. The tumor cells exhibit significant pleomorphism, with large, hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear contours, and prominent nucleoli. There are also areas with apoptotic bodies and potential necrosis. This histology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with a colorectal primary. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma.
